Comment: Immigration, particularly coverage of immigration courts, is notoriously under-reported in my opinion, though there are phenomenal beat reporters. (I’m not that; I’ve been largely focused around civil rights and litigation around the administration broadly, though I’ve covered a lot of immigration-related stories over the last 15 years or so.) Immigration is often not something that has made headlines, unless it’s related to violent crime. I can’t answer why or how that happened, and why news organizations made those decisions. Lately I’ve been thinking a lot about “abolish ICE” being marginalized politically over the years, and I’m curious if/how that will come around again next year and in 2028.  \- Alex

Comment: I think that’s the big question, and why immigration and civil rights lawyers are focused so intensely on the case of Kilmar Abrego Garcia. Say someone who was legally permanently in the country but was swept up in a so-called “collateral arrest” during an immigration enforcement action, or a raid, and that person was put on a bus and then a plane for El Salvador. Trump and administration officials contend that there’s due process for that person to challenge what happened to them, but that’s after the fact, and contingent on a cooperative foreign government. So the mantra among Democrats and other critics has been if it can happen to him, it could happen to anyone; if someone like that is denied due process, then nobody has due process. Obviously the focus from the administration has been on the allegations around Abrego Garcia, which if substantiated in a courtroom could likely end up with his withholding order revoked. But that didn’t happen, and most if not all of the allegations against him haven’t been introduced in court documents in his current case.  \- Alex

Comment: We’ve come a long way from bipartisan support for a “pathway to citizenship.” Polls show most Americans support border security broadly, but the trick is getting into specific questions. Polls show voters support removing people living in the country illegally, and leading up to 2024 elections even suggested support for mass deportations. But I think a lot of those results were misleading. It’s difficult to capture the complexity of the immigration process (shout out immigration beat reporters), and there’s a lot of muddled ideas about what people would consider “legal” when it comes to one’s status, and how they got it.If you break down Pew polls from 2024, you’d see 56 percent of registered voters “strongly or somewhat” favored mass removals, while at the same time, majorities were backing “allowing undocumented immigrants to legally work and stay in the country if they are married to a US citizen” and the ability to “stay in the country legally, if certain requirements are met.” Polling analysts seemed to think it’s not so much a contradiction as it is a clear misunderstanding of what all those things really mean. So I think a few things are happening: Republicans are banking on broad support for something largely misunderstood but aren’t gonna ditch the president’s agenda out of fear of losing that support and also the support from the president and his allies.  \- Alex
Author: theindependentonline

Comment: This whole episode involves a lot, starting with the much-criticized way federal law enforcement identifies gang members. The allegations against Abrego Garcia are mostly being played out in the court of public opinion, and seemingly nowhere on the docket in the ongoing case challenging his removal. The government has not raised allegations of abuse and human trafficking to defend his removal in front of federal judges or the Supreme Court. Allegations of his membership in MS-13 stem from his initial immigration court proceedings that led up to a judge’s order withholding his removal, and those have been revived in the latest proceedings.      ICE guidelines for identifying gang membership are sort of a checklist, based on at least two “gang membership identification criteria,” including tattoos. (ICE has redacted criteria from its guide, which if you wanna read,[ is here](https://www.ice.gov/doclib/foia/policy/handbook_HSI_18-03_08.13.2018.pdf); similar criteria was used to identify alleged Tren de Aragua members under the Alien Enemies Act.) Otherwise, ICE defines a “gang member” as someone “who admits to being in a gang or who has a gang-related conviction.” Abrego Garcia was initially identified by an unnamed informant, backed up by his clothing (Chicago Bulls gear) and tattoos.      So the tattoos became a big focus publicly, and right-wing social media accounts started to speculate that tattoos on his hand are code for MS-13. Then the Trump administration put out a photo, clearly putting those letters and numbers on his hand in an apparent attempt to decode them. I am now not sure whether Trump realizes that’s what happened.  \- Alex
Author: theindependentonline

Comment: I think this will all depend on what happens with their cases in the U.S. and if the administration plays ball. There have been a lot of cases filed across the country after the Supreme Court effectively told the Trump administration that Alien Enemies Act removals can continue only if those targeted have a chance to challenge the allegations. Lawyers in the initial case playing out in Washington D.C. [recently filed an amended complaint](https://storage.courtlistener.com/recap/gov.uscourts.dcd.278436/gov.uscourts.dcd.278436.101.0.pdf) asking the court to order the return of everyone sent to El Salvador under the Alien Enemies Act. So we’ll be closely watching what happens there too.  \- Alex

Comment: It’s unclear right now what the administration is planning, but “denaturalization” isn’t new, it’s just very rare. According to the ACLU, there were roughly 11 per year between 1990 and 2017.      The first Trump administration referred dozens of cases to the DOJ, and ICE intended to review thousands of USCIS cases. Denaturalization can happen for things like treason, enlisting in a foreign military, and lying on an application for naturalization, and there’s a lot of due process involved, but if they were to try to do something sweeping, the administration would likely rely on some other justification (e.g. Alien Enemies Act, etc.) to try to jam them through.  \- Alex
Author: theindependentonline

Comment: Real good question. I was a reporter in New Orleans at the time, and there was a lot of uncertainty and fear around immigration policy in immigrant communities during the end of the Obama and beginning of the Trump administrations, and really similar conversations than we’re having now. In short, Obama inherited Bush-era machinery for a mass deportation agenda and ultimately deported or returned about 3 million people, largely focusing on people with criminal convictions and people who recently crossed the border. Trump reversed the prioritization policy, so there’s been a wider focus on all undocumented people. This term, he also suspended asylum claims at the border and some legal immigration pathways, so there are also fewer people entering the system.       My colleague Alicja Hagopian put together some charts on this last year: [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-deportation-numbers-obama-biden-b2649257.html](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-deportation-numbers-obama-biden-b2649257.html)
Author: theindependentonline
